segment.source: Deny log on as a service (Windows 10)
segment.target: Deny log on as a service (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Deny log on as a service security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Deny log on as a service security policy setting.

segment.source: Deny log on as a service
segment.target: Deny log on as a service

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Deny log on as a service security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Deny log on as a service security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users are prevented from logging on to the service applications on a device.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users are prevented from logging on to the service applications on a device.

segment.source: A service is an application type that runs in the system background without a user interface.
segment.target: A service is an application type that runs in the system background without a user interface.

segment.source: It provides core operating system features, such as web serving, event logging, file serving, printing, cryptography, and error reporting.
segment.target: It provides core operating system features, such as web serving, event logging, file serving, printing, cryptography, and error reporting.

segment.source: When you assign this user right, thoroughly test that the effect is what you intended.
segment.target: When you assign this user right, thoroughly test that the effect is what you intended.

segment.source: Within a domain, modify this setting on the applicable Group Policy Object (GPO).
segment.target: Within a domain, modify this setting on the applicable Group Policy Object (GPO).

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values for the most recent supported versions of Windows.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: On a domain-joined device, including the domain controller, this policy can be overwritten by a domain policy, which will prevent you from modifying the local policy setting.
segment.target: On a domain-joined device, including the domain controller, this policy can be overwritten by a domain policy, which will prevent you from modifying the local policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting might conflict with and negate the Log on as a service setting.
segment.target: This policy setting might conflict with and negate the Log on as a service setting.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Accounts that can log on to a service application could be used to configure and start new unauthorized services, such as a keylogger or other malware.
segment.target: Accounts that can log on to a service application could be used to configure and start new unauthorized services, such as a keylogger or other malware.

segment.source: The benefit of the specified countermeasure is somewhat reduced by the fact that only users with administrative rights can install and configure services, and an attacker who has already attained that level of access could configure the service to run by using the System account.
segment.target: The benefit of the specified countermeasure is somewhat reduced by the fact that only users with administrative rights can install and configure services, and an attacker who has already attained that level of access could configure the service to run by using the System account.

segment.source: We recommend that you not assign the Deny log on as a service user right to any accounts.
segment.target: We recommend that you not assign the Deny log on as a service user right to any accounts.

segment.source: Organizations that are extremely concerned about security might assign this user right to groups and accounts when they are certain that they will never need to log on to a service application.
segment.target: Organizations that are extremely concerned about security might assign this user right to groups and accounts when they are certain that they will never need to log on to a service application.

segment.source: If you assign the Deny log on as a service user right to specific accounts, services may not start and a denial-of-service condition could result.
segment.target: If you assign the Deny log on as a service user right to specific accounts, services may not start and a denial-of-service condition could result.
